positive.review: ⚔️ Despite its rawness and bugs, it's still a solid and good survival game. It has a great medieval barbarian fantasy atmosphere and captures the spirit of Conan's lore. The locations may seem large, but they're actually not that big. They may also seem empty at first, but that's not true either. There are plenty of resource places and points of interest that contain useful items, not junk. The world is completely free to explore, and there's a clear explanation of what you can do (a lot of professions). Even without the overpriced DLC's, there's enough content. The standard difficulty won't let you relax, but it's fair, although the ranges of some weapons can be a challenge, especially on bosses. However, even in singleplayer, you're on a server; there's no pause, you'll have to find secluded spots and monitor your stats, as exiting to the main menu resets your dungeon / quest progress (but even so, items / mobs respawning too fast, requiring adjustments).
This is the title that sparked my love for survival games, with more memories tied to this than any other that I have played over the years. It will always be ‘one of the greats’ in my eyes.

This is one of those reviews where I wish in between thumbs-up and thumbs-down, there was a "meh" button. That's very rare for me. I love gaming. I buy games when I am truly interested in them and the great majority of my reviews are strong positives. 

First... maybe Conan Exiles I just played in the wrong order. If I played it 5 years ago, my opinion would be much more positive. But from where we now are in the survival / crafting / building genre, CE hits me like a dumbed-down Soulmask. I love the genre generally and finding ones with minions / thralls / henchmen is a special sub-cat that I long for. But the CE thralls are so much dumber than in Soulmask. Yeah, they can serve at a workstation, but you only get a benefit if they are a crafter of that time and their bennies apply to the station. There is zero automation. Yeah, they can go with you to a fight, but only one of them, and it doesn't really matter how you equip them--their level will dictate their effectiveness and stats no matter how you gear them. Yuck. Let my previous booty make them better.

In comparison to Soulmask, the CE map also feels empty, with many of the same types of critters scattered around like you were grinding in an MMO region with not nearly the variety of SM's beasts. Crocs and spiders, spiders and crocs... oh, now hyenas. Hyenas everywhere. I thought there would be a mix of cities here, wilderness, and camps, but it's mostly all camps with a few scattered keeps. Overall, these dynamics make the map feel smaller than either SM or Enshrouded--but it still takes forever to get anywhere because fast travel is very sparse and it takes a long time to earn the right to a mount. Multiple bases? Well, okay. But are you going to run back and forth ten times to bring your stations or are you going to speak the hours to farm them all over again? A drag either way. Not what I RPG for.

Where Conan shines is the mix of cultures, including armors (light, medium and heavy), weapons, and detailed building styles. So much more to offer in all those areas than any other survival games bc of the mix of armors and outfits related to the Roman / Greek / China / Japan / Medieval French / barbarian analogues in that lore. Beautiful! And the base-building is nice with lots of fun decor... but the tasks you do there are slow, and not nearly as detailed or automate-able as SM. As a special complaint, while the "Journeys" are a great idea, teaching you in-depth one skill set at a time, the game gives you no help at all understanding your next step. A particular galling one was the need to make bricks to build a planter which is the minimalist way CE does farming. The furnace should be the place where you can see how to make them, but zippo. I was confused. Real bricks are made of molded clay and baked. In CE, with no info to indicate it, you bake rocks. What? Yes, rocks. Go brake a rock, stick the pieces in the furnace, and bake. Presto, bricks! Not only does it make no sense--I couldn't find it intuitively. There is also no tip in the furnace UI nor the journey. Frustrating.

So, here's CE. A behind-the-times by a decade survival, crafting, building game with minions. Beautiful in the breadth of its lore. Skinny everywhere else.

I want to preface that while I love this game, I avoided it for a very long time and even when I did cave and buy it, I came [b]very[/b] close to returning it because it feels very poorly made. Many aspects of the game are extremely dated or janky, Particularly the UI looks especially low quality. Even for the time this game came out, it just doesn't look very pretty or play particularly well. 200 Hours later, I am willing to recommend this game, but with a lot of Caveats. I am not going to speak about PVP in this game as I don't really enjoy engaging in it, and it's rather dead/inactive at this time.

The Combat is really not great. You can tell this game released during the "Souls-like" Hype era where iframe dodge rolls and weighty animations were in almost every action game, but it misses that mark. Attack animations from even the lightest weapons still manage to feel sluggish, yet floaty at the same time. Certain attacks can just stunlock you endlessly, while others wind up for a year just to tickle the enemy. It's really not great and balance is all over the place, despite Funcom regularly nerfing "overpowered" weapons. Information and stats on the wiki also regularly do not match what is in the game, so it is difficult to confirm information about anything due to largely outdated or inaccurate sources. 

Building on the other hand is simple yet robust. It follows the standard no-grid, foundation-based snapping build systems many survival games use with a Valheim-like stability system. But I have two gripes with Building: First, many of the games' structures and numerous crafting benches are way too large (the map room and animal pen are both 7 x 7 foundations wide), meaning you need a lot of space and have to make a pretty large base. But the world really lacks in good, flat areas to build and there is no way to terraform outside of stacking foundations. Additionally, in Singleplayer, building is rather pointless. Your base does not [b]ever[/b] get attacked unless you intentionally call a "Purge" to siege your own base. Obviously not the case in PVP, which is largely dead, but in PvE Singleplayer, Basebuilding is literally just to make a large area to hold the 20+ different Crafting benches. It is fun though if you are into building specifically.  

The Thrall System is probably the most unique aspect of Conan Exiles. You can rescue or capture various crafters and fighters, convert them to your faction, and position them to guard your base, travel with you as a bodyguard or help with crafting items (Crafters do not craft for you, but they do increase craft speed and the quality of items crafted. There is a surprising amount of depth to this system in terms of traits, appearances, etc. The caveat with this system is that it is extremely prone to glitches, most infamously that thralls can just glitch and disappear from your world, permanently removed without any explanation. The chance of this is significantly reduced by disabling the "Living Settlements" feature, which causes thralls to walk around and socialize with each other. But to this day, there is still no true fix for this issue and the feature is outright disabled on official servers.

Finally, Monetization. This is probably the most controversial aspect of Conan Exiles. Not only is there over $100 worth of Paid Cosmetic DLC Packs (most of which is Building sets themed after a certain culture), but there was also formerly a Paid Battle Pass which was replaced with a Paid Shop known as the Black Lotus Bazaar, where you can buy microtransactions using a premium currency known as "Crom Coins." The Community is pretty much united on the fact that these Shop Items are disgustingly overpriced, Flamboyant Feasts for example is a Dining Table that costs nearly $27, though they regularly list it "discounted" for $17. This is significantly worse value than the Previous DLC system where you would get 3 full sets of armour, dozens of building pieces, decorations and weapons that were all thematically cohesive with each other, for around $10. As an added Caveat, Cosmetics and Items purchased via the Bazaar cannot be used in Offline Play. Should the servers close, all of those cosmetics will be gone with no way to recover them. This is not even mentioning the price to Host/Rent a server for online play and the game costing $40-50 on Steam, depending on Region. For what it is, this game is needlessly expensive and the developers seemingly haven't directed any of these funds towards actually fixing core issues with the game, such as Thrall Loss glitches mentioned above.

If any of those are deal breakers, I would say Palworld is extremely similar and way more reasonable in terms of cost for what you get, despite totally different art directions. And if you already played Palworld and liked it, I am confident you will enjoy this game as the Building and Crafting Systems are very similar, and the thrall system is functionally identical to the Pal system in Palworld in that you capture slaves and put them to labor. Both games are also a bit janky, but work fine enough. I would argue Palworld's "thrall" system is a little more satisfying and interesting, but that Conan has better base building and much better character customization, equipment and general gameplay. If you like one, you will probably like the other, though Conan Exiles has much less ethical monetization compared to Palworld's constant free Updates.

Conan Exiles: A Savage, Rewarding, and Epic Survival Sandbox

Rating: Highly Recommended / A Must-Play for the Genre

Funcom's Conan Exiles isn't just another entry in the crowded survival genre—it's a brutal, bloody, and beautiful spectacle that carves out its own niche. Set in the savage world of Robert E. Howard’s legendary barbarian, this game provides an unparalleled sense of scale, freedom, and true conquest. If you're looking for a survival experience that emphasizes epic building, rewarding exploration, and visceral combat, your journey in the Exiled Lands begins now.

The Good: What Sets it Apart

1. The Exiled Lands: A World of Grand Scale and Detail
The map is simply huge, featuring stunningly diverse biomes that feel handcrafted and steeped in lore. From the scorching southern deserts and dense eastern jungles to the frozen north and the volcanic lava fields, every region presents a new survival challenge. The ability to climb almost any surface fundamentally changes exploration, making you feel like a true adventurer looking down on the world you aim to conquer. Finding ancient ruins, hidden dungeons, and cryptic lore notes is genuinely rewarding, creating a cohesive and deep fantasy world.

2. Building is King: Unleash Your Inner Architect
The building system in Conan Exiles is arguably the best in the survival space. It’s intuitive, flexible, and allows for massive, architecturally complex structures. Whether you want to build a sprawling medieval fortress, a secluded cliffside base, or a humble riverside village, the variety of building pieces and aesthetics (especially with the DLC packs) is immense. Successfully defending your massive base during The Purge (an NPC army invasion) gives an incredible feeling of hard-earned permanence and accomplishment.

3. Thralls, Religion, and Sorcery: Unique Systems for Domination
The Thrall system is a fantastic, thematic feature. Capturing NPCs, breaking their will on the Wheel of Pain, and then employing them as guards, crafters, or entertainers adds a layer of depth other games lack. Furthermore, the introduction of the Sorcery system has added an exciting new dimension to the endgame, allowing players to corrupt their bodies for dark magic, summon demons, and even ride winged monstrosities. And for true scale, few things top summoning a massive God Avatar to crush your enemies’ fortifications—it’s pure, over-the-top Conan fantasy.

4. Visceral and Brutal Combat
Combat is fast-paced, action-oriented, and unapologetically bloody. With a wide variety of weapon types, light and heavy attack combos, and the need for well-timed dodges and blocks, fights feel substantial and decisive. The M-rated gore visuals are a key part of the experience, delivering the brutality you expect from the Conan universe.

The Drawbacks (And Why They Don't Ruin the Fun)

Like any massive open-world survival title, Conan Exiles isn't without its jank. New players should be prepared for a steep initial learning curve, as the Journey system, while helpful, doesn't immediately explain the deep crafting and thrall mechanics. Additionally, the game has had its share of bugs over the years, though Funcom has consistently released large updates to improve quality of life and polish. If you can push past the first few hours of struggle, you'll find the deep systems waiting to reward your persistence.

Final Verdict

Conan Exiles is a triumph of fantasy survival. It succeeds where many others fail by delivering not just a sandbox, but a rich, atmospheric world where you truly feel like you are earning your power from nothing. The unparalleled building freedom, the massive scope of the map, and the satisfying progression from a naked exile to a powerful warlord or sorcerer make this a highly recommended purchase. Grab your friends, choose your god, and carve out your own legend in the Exiled Lands.

Conan Exiles is an open-world survival game developed by Funcom, set in the brutal universe of Conan the Barbarian.

The gameplay revolves around gathering resources, crafting tools and weapons, building settlements, and surviving in a hostile desert landscape. Players begin with nothing and must manage hunger, thirst, and shelter while defending themselves against creatures, NPC factions, and other players in online modes.

Combat is real-time and melee-focused. Weapons include swords, spears, bows, and improvised tools. Blocking, dodging, and stamina management are essential, and progression unlocks stronger gear and crafting recipes. The system is simple but effective, especially in co-op or PvP play.

The world is large and diverse, featuring deserts, jungles, frozen mountains, and ancient ruins. Exploration rewards materials, lore fragments, and hidden dungeons. Environmental hazards and weather effects increase survival tension.

Building is one of the game’s strongest features. Players can construct anything from small shelters to massive fortresses, using an intuitive placement system. Thralls—NPCs captured and enslaved—can be assigned as workers or guards, adding depth to settlement management.

Visually, Conan Exiles uses the Unreal Engine to create detailed landscapes and character models. The aesthetic is gritty and violent, consistent with Robert E. Howard’s source material. Performance is stable on most systems, though large builds and online servers can cause occasional slowdowns.

Overall, Conan Exiles is a robust survival sandbox that balances crafting, combat, and exploration within a harsh, mature setting. It rewards long-term investment and creativity but demands patience and resource management. Ideal for players who enjoy open-world survival with a darker, more visceral tone.

Pros: Sandbox map done correctly, impressive places to explore, satisfying building mechanics, freedom of character creation and customization, roleplay potential, great modding community.

Cons: Physics more broken than a Bethesda title, fighting mechanics are frustratingly awful.

I can't decide if I like the game or not, the only 2 cons overshadow the pros this game has. Your character will be stunlocked with every bit of damage it takes, which isn't that bad in a 1v1 but the game often throws hordes at you. If you are facing more than 3 enemies at once there's no skill involved, you are facing with a win and lose condition. If the enemy strikes you once, even if you take just a tiny bit of damage, the other enemies will attack right after, getting you stunned again. You will wait hopelessly as you watch your health drain with no way out of the situation. If you aren't the one to strike first you DIE. 
You can forget about dodging, both enemies and companions will block any way you have of getting out of a sticky situation. At worst you will get stuck in the physics, defenseless, with the enemy stabbing at you. You will die to the buggy environtment more often than not.
The fighting mechanics as they are heavily incentivises using a one heanded melee with a shield, so you can forget about freedom of customization or roleplaying if you wanna get somewhere.
Because of this, exploration is more frustrating than fun. There are no stealth mechanics, nor AOE options that won't hurt you as well, meaning your only choices are between melee fights or fleeing .

TLDR: as much as I like it, I honestly can't recommend it. If you want the experience this game has to offer I'd suggest Palworld, same pros without the cons, +guns, +better follower AI.
